maml:description.maml:para: Returns a Windows Azure SQL Database either from the specified SQL Database Server connection context or from a specified SQL Database Server.

Use the Get-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet to retrieve a SQL Database by name either from the specified SQL Database Server connection context or from a specified SQL Database Server. You can create a SQL Database Server connection context using the New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerContext cmdlet, and then use it with this cmdlet.

When you retrieve a database by specifying a SQL Database Server, the Get-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet creates a temporary connection context using the specified SQL Database Server name and the current Windows Azure subscription information to perform the operation.
If the database name is not specified, the Get-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet returns all SQL Databases for the specified connection context or SQL Database Server.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server from where to retrieve a SQL database.
A database object representing the SQL Database to be retrieved.
The name of the SQL Database to be retrieved.
The name of SQL Database Server from where to retrieve the database.
A database object representing the SQL Database to be retrieved.
The name of the SQL Database to be retrieved.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server from where to retrieve a SQL database.
A database object representing the SQL Database to be retrieved.
The name of the SQL Database to be retrieved.
The name of SQL Database Server from where to retrieve the database.

Note: Some of the metadata returned by this output object are associated with the preview of Windows Azure SQL Database Premium Edition. Only participants in the preview are able to use this data. To learn more about the preview, please see http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=308949.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example returns the database, "Database1", from the specified SQL Database Server connection context “$ctx”.
This example returns the database, "Database1", from the specified SQL Database Server "lpqd0zbr8y".

maml:description.maml:para: Returns the status of an import or export operation between Windows Azure blob storage and a Windows Azure SQL Database.

This cmdlet returns the status of an import or export request initiated by the Start-AzureSqlDatabaseImport or Start-AzureSqlDatabaseExport cmdlet. You can specify the request object with the Request parameter, or you can identify the request with the RequestId parameter along with the Username, Password, and ServerName parameters.
If RequestId is specified, the user name required to connect to the Azure SQL Database Server.
If RequestId is specified, the password required to connect to the Azure SQL Database Server.
If RequestId is specified, the name of the Azure SQL Database Server.
The GUID of the import or export operation for which to return status. This parameter requires the UserName, Password, and ServerName parameters.
The ImportExportRequest object representing the import or export request, as returned by the Start-AzureSqlDatabaseImport or Start-AzureSqlDatabaseExport cmdlet.
If RequestId is specified, the password required to connect to the Azure SQL Database Server.
The ImportExportRequest object representing the import or export request, as returned by the Start-AzureSqlDatabaseImport or Start-AzureSqlDatabaseExport cmdlet.
The GUID of the import or export operation for which to return status. This parameter requires the UserName, Password, and ServerName parameters.
If RequestId is specified, the name of the Azure SQL Database Server.
If RequestId is specified, the user name required to connect to the Azure SQL Database Server.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example returns the status of an export request

maml:description.maml:para: Returns information about the Windows Azure SQL Database Servers in the current subscription.

If a SQL Database Server name is specified in the ServerName parameter, the cmdlet returns an object with information about the specific SQL Database Server. Otherwise, it returns information about all the SQL Database Servers.

The name of the SQL Database Server for which you want to retrieve information. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name. If not specified, information about all the SQL Database Servers in the current subscription is returned.

The name of the SQL Database Server for which you want to retrieve information. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name. If not specified, information about all the SQL Database Servers in the current subscription is returned.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns information about all of the SQL Database Servers in the current subscription.
This command returns information about the “lpqd0zbr8y” server.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns firewall rules in the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server in the current subscription.

If a firewall rule name is specified in the RuleName parameter, the cmdlet returns information about the specific firewall rule. Otherwise, information about all the firewall rules in the specified SQL Database Server is listed.
The name of the SQL Database Server for which you want to retrieve the firewall rules. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
The name of the firewall rule to retrieve. If not specified, information about all the firewall rules in the specified SQL Database Server is listed.
The name of the firewall rule to retrieve. If not specified, information about all the firewall rules in the specified SQL Database Server is listed.
The name of the SQL Database Server for which you want to retrieve the firewall rules. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns all the firewall rules in the specified SQL Database Server (“lpqd0zbr8y”).
This command returns the specified firewall rule (“myRule”) in the specified SQL Database Server (“lpqd0zbr8y”).

maml:description.maml:para: Returns the quota information for a specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.
The user specifies the server by supplying a connection context. If a quota name is not specified, then all the quota information for the server is returned.
The connection context to the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.
The name of the quota value to be retrieved. If a quota name is not specified, then all the quota information for the server is returned.
The connection context to the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.
The name of the quota value to be retrieved. If a quota name is not specified, then all the quota information for the server is returned.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example returns the quota, "Premium_Databases", from the Windows Azure SQL Database Server specified by the connection $ctx.
This example returns a list of all quota values from the Windows Azure SQL Database Server specified by the connection $ctx.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns a service objective for the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.
If the service objective is not specified, this cmdlet returns all service objectives for the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.

Note: This cmdlet is part of the preview of Windows Azure SQL Database Premium Edition. Only participants in the preview are able to use this cmdlet. To learn more about the preview, please see http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=308949.
The connection context to the specified SQL Database Server.
The name of the service objective to return. If not specified, then all the service objectives for the SQL Database Server are returned.
The connection context to the specified SQL Database Server.
An object representing the service objective to return. If not specified, then all the service objectives for the SQL Database Server are returned.
The connection context to the specified SQL Database Server.
An object representing the service objective to return. If not specified, then all the service objectives for the SQL Database Server are returned.
The name of the service objective to return. If not specified, then all the service objectives for the SQL Database Server are returned.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------
command:example.dev:code: C:\PS>Get-SqlServiceObjective $ctx | Format-Table Name, State, DateCreated, IsDefault, CreatedBy

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example displays all the service objectives for the SQL Database Server specified by the connection $ctx.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new Windows Azure SQL Database either for the specified SQL Database Server connection context or in the specified SQL Database Server.

The New-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet creates a new SQL Database either for the specified SQL Database Server connection context or in the specified SQL Database Server. You can create a SQL Database Server connection context using the New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerContext cmdlet, and then use it with this cmdlet.

When you create a new database by specifying a SQL Database Server, the New-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet creates a temporary connection context using the specified SQL Database Server name and the current Windows Azure subscription information to perform the operation.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server where you want to create new SQL Database.
The name of the new database.
Collation for the newly created SQL Database.
The edition for the SQL Database. Acceptable values are Web and Business. The default value is Web.
Allows the action to complete without prompting the user for confirmation.
The maximum size for the database in gigabytes. The acceptable values differ based on edition.
Web Edition values: 1 or 5
Business Edition values: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 100, or 150
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
The SQL Database Server name where you want to create new SQL Database.
The name of the new database.
Collation for the newly created SQL Database.
The edition for the SQL Database. Acceptable values are Web and Business. The default value is Web.
Allows the action to complete without prompting the user for confirmation.
The maximum size for the database in gigabytes. The acceptable values differ based on edition.
Web Edition values: 1 or 5
Business Edition values: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 100, or 150
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Collation for the newly created SQL Database.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server where you want to create new SQL Database.
The name of the new database.
The edition for the SQL Database. Acceptable values are Web and Business. The default value is Web.
Allows the action to complete without prompting the user for confirmation.
The maximum size for the database in gigabytes. The acceptable values differ based on edition.
Web Edition values: 1 or 5
Business Edition values: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 100, or 150
The SQL Database Server name where you want to create new SQL Database.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

maml:alert.maml:para: To delete a database that was created by New-AzureSqlDatabase, use the Remove-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates a new SQL Database with the name, "Database1", for the specified SQL Database Server connection context “$ctx”.
This example creates a new database with the name, "Database1", in the specified SQL Database Server "lpqd0zbr8y".

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new Windows Azure SQL Database Server in the current subscription.
The New-AzureSqlDatabaseServer cmdlet creates a new SQL Database Server in the current subscription.
Administrator account name for your new SQL Database Server.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
Administrator account password for your new SQL Database Server. You must specify a strong password. For more information, see Strong Passwords (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=154152).
Region or location where the new SQL Database Server is created. The location determines which datacenter the database will reside in.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Administrator account name for your new SQL Database Server.
Administrator account password for your new SQL Database Server. You must specify a strong password. For more information, see Strong Passwords (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=154152).
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
Region or location where the new SQL Database Server is created. The location determines which datacenter the database will reside in.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a SQL Database Server.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new connection context to the specified SQL Database Server by using SQL Server authentication or certificate-based authentication.

Use the New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerContext cmdlet with SQL Server authentication to create a new connection context to the specified SQL Database Server by using the specified credentials. The SQL Database Server may be specified by name, by the fully-qualified name, or by URL. The credential can be specified using the Get-Credential cmdlet that prompts you to specify the user name and password in a dialog box.

Use the New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerContext cmdlet with certificate-based authentication to create a new connection context to the specified SQL Database Server by using the specified Windows Azure subscription data. The SQL Database Server may be specified by name or by the fully-qualified name. The subscription data can either be specified as a parameter or it can be retrieved from the current Windows Azure subscription (use the Select-AzureSubscription cmdlet to select the current Windows Azure subscription).
The name of the SQL Database Server.
A credential object that provides SQL Server authentication for the user to access the server.
The URL to access the Windows Azure SQL Database Management Portal for the server.
A credential object that provides SQL Server authentication for the user to access the server.
The name of the SQL Database Server.
The fully qualified domain name (FQDN) name for the SQL Database Server. For example, ServerName.database.windows.net.
A credential object that provides SQL Server authentication for the user to access the server.
The fully qualified domain name (FQDN) name for the SQL Database Server. For example, ServerName.database.windows.net.
Indicates that Windows Azure subscription will be used for creating the connection context.

The Windows Azure subscription data object to be used for creating the connection context. The subscription value specified for the parameter will be used for creating the connection context. If you do not use this parameter, the cmdlet uses the current Windows Azure subscription (set using the Select-AzureSubscription cmdlet) to create the connection context.
The name of the SQL Database Server.
Indicates that Windows Azure subscription will be used for creating the connection context.

The Windows Azure subscription data object to be used for creating the connection context. The subscription value specified for the parameter will be used for creating the connection context. If you do not use this parameter, the cmdlet uses the current Windows Azure subscription (set using the Select-AzureSubscription cmdlet) to create the connection context.
A credential object that provides SQL Server authentication for the user to access the server.
The fully qualified domain name (FQDN) name for the SQL Database Server. For example, ServerName.database.windows.net.
The URL to access the Windows Azure SQL Database Management Portal for the server.
The name of the SQL Database Server.

The Windows Azure subscription data object to be used for creating the connection context. The subscription value specified for the parameter will be used for creating the connection context. If you do not use this parameter, the cmdlet uses the current Windows Azure subscription (set using the Select-AzureSubscription cmdlet) to create the connection context.
Indicates that Windows Azure subscription will be used for creating the connection context.

maml:alert.maml:para: If you authenticated without specifying a domain, then if you are using PowerShell 2.0, the Get-Credential cmdlet returns a backslash prepended to the username, for example, "\user" (PowerShell 3.0 does not add the backslash). This backslash is not recognized by the -Credential parameter of the New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerContext cmdlet. To remove it, use code similar to the following:

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
C:\PS>$cred = Get-Credential
C:\PS>$ctx = New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerContext -ServerName "lpqd0zbr8y" -credential $cred
C:\PS>$database1 = New-AzureSqlDatabase -ConnectionContext $ctx -DatabaseName "Database1" -MaxSizeGB 50 -Collation "SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example uses the SQL Server authentication. It prompts the user for server administrator credentials, connects to the specified SQL Database Server, "lpqd0zbr8y", using those credentials, and creates a new database, “Database1”, on the server.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
C:\PS>$subId = <Subscription ID>
C:\PS>$thumbprint = <Certificate Thumbprint> C:\PS>$myCert = Get-Item Cert:\CurrentUser\My\$thumbprint
C:\PS> Set-AzureSubscription -SubscriptionName "mySubscription" -SubscriptionId $subId -Certificate $myCert
---------------------------------------------------------
C:\PS>Select-AzureSubscription -SubscriptionName "mySubscription"
C:\PS>$ctx = New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerContext -ServerName "lpqd0zbr8y" -UseSubscription

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example uses the certificate-based authentication. The first four commands set common parameters including a subscription ID and certificate for the subscription "mySubscription". These four commands need to be run once per subscription per machine. The rest of the commands select the subscription "mySubscription" to be designated as the current subscription, and then the current subscription is used to create the connection context to the specified SQL Database Server, "lpqd0zbr8y".

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new firewall rule in the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server in the current subscription.
The New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet creates a new firewall rule in the specified SQL Database Server.
Use the cmdlet with the IpRange parameter set to allow any IP address within the range specified in the StartIpAddress and EndIpAddress parameters to connect to the SQL Database Server.

Use the cmdlet with the AllowAllAzureServices parameter set to allow Windows Azure connections to the SQL Database Server. A firewall rule with starting and ending IP addresses equal to 0.0.0.0 will be created. If you do not specify a firewall rule name, a firewall rule with default name “AllowAllAzureServices” will be created.
The name of the SQL Database Server where the new firewall rule is created. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
End value of the IP address range.
New SQL Database firewall rule name.
Start value of the IP address range.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
The name of the SQL Database Server where the new firewall rule is created. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
New SQL Database firewall rule name.
Allows Windows Azure connections to the SQL Database Server.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Allows Windows Azure connections to the SQL Database Server.
End value of the IP address range.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
New SQL Database firewall rule name.
The name of the SQL Database Server where the new firewall rule is created. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Start value of the IP address range.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new firewall rule (“myRule1”) in the specified SQL Database Server (“lpqd0zbr8y”) with the specified IP range values.
This command creates a new firewall rule (“myRule2”) in the specified SQL Database Server (“lpqd0zbr8y”) to allow Windows Azure connections.
This command creates a new firewall rule with the default firewall rule name (“AllowAllAzureServices”) in the specified SQL Database Server (“lpqd0zbr8y”) to allow Windows Azure connections.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes a Windows Azure SQL Database from the specified SQL Database Server connection context or SQL Database Server.

The Remove-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet deletes a SQL Database from the specified SQL Database Server connection context or SQL Database Server. You can create a SQL Database Server connection context using the New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerContext cmdlet, and then use it with this cmdlet.

When you delete a database by specifying a SQL Database Server, the Remove-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet creates a temporary connection context using the specified SQL Database Server name and the current Windows Azure subscription information to perform the operation.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server where you want to delete a SQL Database.
The name of the SQL Database to be removed.
Allows the action to complete without prompting the user for confirmation.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server where you want to delete a SQL Database.
A database object representing the database to be removed.

The name of SQL Database Server where you want to delete the database.
A database object representing the database to be removed.

Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
The name of SQL Database Server where you want to delete the database.
The name of the SQL Database to be removed.
Allows the action to complete without prompting the user for confirmation.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server where you want to delete a SQL Database.
A database object representing the database to be removed.
The name of the SQL Database to be removed.
Allows the action to complete without prompting the user for confirmation.
The name of SQL Database Server where you want to delete the database.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server from the current subscription.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets properties for a Windows Azure SQL Database either in the specified SQL Database Server connection context or in the specified SQL Database Server.

The Set-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet sets properties either for the specified SQL Database in a SQL Database Server connection context or a SQL Database Server. You can specify the database by name or pass a SQL Database object through the pipeline.

When you set a database property in a specified SQL Database Server, the Set-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet creates a temporary connection context using the specified SQL Database Server name and the current Windows Azure subscription information to perform the operation.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server where you want to modify a SQL Database.
The name of the SQL Database to modify.
If specified, the new edition for the SQL Database. Acceptable values are Web and Business.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
If specified, the new maximum size for the database in gigabytes. The acceptable values differ based on edition.
Web Edition values: 1 or 5
Business Edition values: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 100, or 150
If specified, the new name of the SQL Database.
Returns the input object.
If specified, an object representing the new service objective for this database.

Note: This parameter is a feature of the preview of Windows Azure SQL Database Premium Edition. Only participants in the preview are able to use this parameter. To learn more about the preview, please see http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=308949.

Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates the properties of the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server in the current subscription.

The Set-AzureSqlDatabaseServer cmdlet updates the properties of the specified SQL Database Server. In the current release, you can only update the administrator account password for a SQL Database Server.
The name of the SQL Database Server to be updated. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
The new Administrator account password for your SQL Database Server. You must specify a strong password. For more information, see Strong Passwords (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=154152).
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
The new Administrator account password for your SQL Database Server. You must specify a strong password. For more information, see Strong Passwords (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=154152).
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
The name of the SQL Database Server to be updated. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command updates the administrator account password for the SQL Database Server (“lpqd0zbr8y”) with the new password (“myNewP@ssword”).

maml:description.maml:para: Updates the properties of an existing firewall rule in the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.
The Set-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet updates the start IP address and end IP address values of an existing firewall rule in the specified SQL Database Server.
Name of the SQL Database Server that contains the firewall rule to be updated. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
The new end IP address value.
Name of the SQL Database Server firewall rule to be updated.
The new start IP address value.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
The new end IP address value.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
Name of the SQL Database Server firewall rule to be updated.
Name of the SQL Database Server that contains the firewall rule to be updated. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
The new start IP address value.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command updates the start IP address and end IP address of the firewall rule (“myRule”) in the SQL Database Server (“lpqd0zbr8y”).

maml:description.maml:para: Initiates an export operation from a Windows Azure SQL Database to Windows Azure blob storage.

Use the Start-AzureSqlDatabaseExport cmdlet to initiate an export operation from an Azure SQL Database to blob storage. The operation requires a database server connection context. Use the Get-AzureSqlDatabaseImportExportStatus cmdlet to get status on the export operation.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server containing the SQL Database.
The blob storage container object into which the data is exported.
The name of the database from which the data is exported.
The name of the blob storage into which to export the database.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server containing the SQL Database.
The context of the blob storage.
The name of the storage container containing the blob into which the data is exported.
The name of the database from which the data is exported.
The name of the blob storage into which to export the database.
The name of the blob storage into which to export the database.
The name of the database from which the data is exported.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server containing the SQL Database.
The blob storage container object into which the data is exported.
The name of the storage container containing the blob into which the data is exported.
The context of the blob storage.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
C:\PS>$credential = Get-Credential
C:\PS>$SqlCtx = New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerContext -ServerName $ServerName -Credentials $credential
C:\PS>$StorageCtx = New-AzureStorageContext -StorageAccountName $StorageName -StorageAccountKey $StorageKey
C:\PS>$Container = Get-AzureStorageContainer -Name $ContainerName -Context $StorageCtx
C:\PS>$exportRequest = Start-AzureSqlDatabaseExport -SqlConnectionContext $SqlCtx -StorageContainer $Container -DatabaseName $DatabaseName -BlobName $BlobName

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example initiates an export process from the SQL Database, "$DatabaseName", to the blob storage, "$BlobName".

maml:description.maml:para: Initiates an import operation from Windows Azure blob storage to an Azure SQL Database.

Use the Start-AzureSqlDatabaseImport cmdlet to initiate an import operation from blob storage to an Azure SQL Database. If the database does not exist, it is created using the size and edition values specified. The operation requires a database server connection context. Use the Get-AzureSqlDatabaseImportExportStatus cmdlet to get status on the import operation.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server containing the SQL Database.
The context of the blob storage.
The name of the blob storage.
The name of the database into which the data is imported. If the database does not exist, it is created with this name.
The name of the blob storage from which to import the database.
If the database does not exist, it is created with this maximum size in gigabytes. The acceptable values differ based on edition.
Web Edition values: 1 or 5
Business Edition values: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 100, or 150
If the database does not exist, it is created as this edition. Acceptable values are Web and Business. The default is Web.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server containing the SQL Database.
The name of the storage container containing the blob from which to import.
The name of the database into which the data is imported. If the database does not exist, it is created with this name.
The name of the blob storage from which to import the database.
If the database does not exist, it is created with this maximum size in gigabytes. The acceptable values differ based on edition.
Web Edition values: 1 or 5
Business Edition values: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 100, or 150
If the database does not exist, it is created as this edition. Acceptable values are Web and Business. The default is Web.
The name of the blob storage from which to import the database.
If the database does not exist, it is created with this maximum size in gigabytes. The acceptable values differ based on edition.
Web Edition values: 1 or 5
Business Edition values: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 100, or 150
The name of the database into which the data is imported. If the database does not exist, it is created with this name.
If the database does not exist, it is created as this edition. Acceptable values are Web and Business. The default is Web.
The connection context to a SQL Database Server containing the SQL Database.
The name of the storage container containing the blob from which to import.
The name of the blob storage.
The context of the blob storage.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
C:\PS>$credential = Get-Credential
C:\PS>$SqlCtx = New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerContext -ServerName $ServerName -Credentials $credential
C:\PS>$StorageCtx = New-AzureStorageContext -StorageAccountName $StorageName -StorageAccountKey $StorageKey
C:\PS>$Container = Get-AzureStorageContainer -Name $ContainerName -Context $StorageCtx
C:\PS>$importRequest = Start-AzureSqlDatabaseImport -SqlConnectionContext $SqlCtx -StorageContainer $Container -DatabaseName $DatabaseName -BlobName $BlobName

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example initiates an import process from the blob storage, "$BlobName", into the SQL Database, "DatabaseName".
